article.Heading: Budget 2016: FM commits to containing fiscal deficit at 3.5% of GDP in FY17
article.Summary: Jaitley had set a tall target of containing India's fiscal deficit to 3.9 percent this fiscal year, 3.5 percent in FY17 and 3 percent in FY18
article.Body:
Finance minister Arun Jaitley once again reiterated his commitment to containing fiscal deficit at 3.5 percent of GDP in FY17. He also said the government will be able to meet its FY16 fiscal deficit target at 3.9 percent of GDP.

He also also sought to assure that the development agenda will not take a backseat and a committee would be set up to review the working of Fiscal Resposibility and Budget Management (FRBM).

He said: "Different schools of thought have argued either in favour of fiscal consolidation and stability or for a less aggressive consolidation and for boosting growth. I have weighed the policy options and decided that prudence lies in adhering to the fiscal targets. Consequently, the fiscal deficit in RE 2015-16 and BE 2016-17 have been retained at 3.9 percent and 3.5 percent of GDP respectively. While doing so, I have ensured that the development agenda has not been compromised."

Jaitley had set a tall target of containing India's fiscal deficit to 3.9 percent this fiscal year, 3.5 percent in FY17 and 3 percent in FY18.

In recent times, this 3.5 percent target had become the focus point of many a debates with many arguing that the government can loosen the fisc to push growth as long as the quality of the fisc is maintained.

The Reserve Bank governor Raghuram Rajan on the other hand has repeatedly warned that such a move will be hazardous for India's long-term prospects and one must not look at short-term gains while foregoing long-term benefits.
